output.project: IoT-based Outdoor Air Quality Monitoring System for Smart Cities
output.concept: Deploy low-power edge nodes with PM2.5 and VOC sensing, solar powered where feasible, communicating via cellular/WiFi/LoRa to a cloud dashboard for real-time air quality analytics across Nigerian urban areas.
research: World Health Organization. WHO Global Air Quality Guidelines.
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The Air Sensor Toolbox.
Castell N, et al. Can commercial low-cost sensors deliver reliable data? Environment International, 2017.
Snyder JC, et al. The Air Sensor Toolbox: A practical approach to low-cost sensors. J Air Waste Manag Assoc, 2016.

problems_overall.problem: Harsh outdoor environment causing sensor drift and enclosure ingress.
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Use IP65+ enclosure, desiccants, and environmental shielding; apply routine calibration checks and weatherproof cabling.

problems_overall.problem: Power reliability for remote/urban deployments with outages.
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Adopt solar+primary battery with low-power duty cycling; include a small mains backup option where grid power is available.
Design with multi-network options (cellular, LoRaWAN, WiFi) and onboard buffering for offline periods.

problems_overall.problem: Calibration and data quality across diverse sensors.
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Implement periodic co-location with a reference monitor and in-field drift correction using cross-sensor data fusion.

options.name: Plantower PMS5003 PM2.5 sensor
options.why_it_works: Low-cost, widely used for outdoor PM monitoring.
options.availability: Widely available from local distributors; 1–2 weeks supply

options.name: Sensirion SPS30 PM sensor
options.why_it_works: Higher accuracy and stability than basic PM sensors.

options.name: BME680 (gas + temp/humidity)
options.why_it_works: Provides VOC/air quality proxy with environmental context.
cons: No PM measurement; must be paired with PM sensor

options.name: CCS811 gas sensor
options.why_it_works: Low-cost VOC/eCO2 estimation for indoor/outdoor use.

options.name: ESP32-WROOM-32D
cons: Limited real-time performance compared to SBCs

options.name: Raspberry Pi 4 Model B (2GB/4GB)
options.why_it_works: Full Linux environment for advanced processing and analytics.

options.name: Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W
options.why_it_works: Compact edge device with adequate compute for lightweight tasks.

options.name: Solar panel + Li-ion battery pack
options.why_it_works: Off-grid, suitable for outdoor deployments with sun exposure.

options.name: Mains adapter + UPS backup
options.why_it_works: Reliable urban deployments with grid access.

options.name: USB power bank with regulator
options.why_it_works: Low-cost portable solution for temporary deployments.

options.name: LTE-M / NB-IoT cellular module (e.g., BG95-M3)
options.why_it_works: Broad coverage in Nigeria with low power for remote sensors.

options.name: WiFi direct to local gateway (ESP32-based)
options.why_it_works: Low-cost, high-bandwidth if local network exists.

options.name: LoRaWAN module with gateway
options.why_it_works: Long-range, low-power comms suitable for city-scale deployments.

output.skills: IoT hardware integration, embedded software (C/Python), edge data processing, sensor calibration, cloud data ingestion, dashboard development (Grafana/Power BI).
suggestions: Use IP65/IP66-rated enclosures with passive cooling for outdoor sensors.
Implement duty cycling and data buffering to handle connectivity gaps.
Plan for sensor co-location trials to calibrate PM and gas sensors against a reference monitor.
Deploy a scalable cloud architecture with secure APIs and role-based access.
Develop a maintenance plan including sensor replacement schedules and enclosure cleaning.
